title: Forking a Repository üç¥
ques:
You want to contribute to an open-source project but don't have write access. 

What is the first step you should take to create a copy of the repository under your own GitHub account?
explanation: **Forking** creates a personal copy of someone else's project. You can submit changes back to the original project via a Pull Request.

title: Cloning a Repository ‚¨áÔ∏è
ques:
You have found a repository `https://github.com/example/project.git`. 

Write the command to download a copy of it to your local machine.
explanation: **`git clone`** copies a remote repository to your local machine, including all files, history, and branches.

title: GitHub Actions Configuration ‚öôÔ∏è
ques: In which directory inside your repository must you place your GitHub Actions workflow YAML files?
explanation: GitHub looks for workflow files in the **`.github/workflows/`** directory. Files here must have a **`.yml`** or **`.yaml`** extension.

title: Starring a Repository ‚≠ê
ques: What is the primary purpose of **starring** a repository on GitHub?
explanation: Starring allows you to keep track of projects you find interesting and helps the creator know their project is appreciated.

title: Issues vs. Pull Requests ü§º
ques: Which GitHub feature is used to **discuss** bugs or feature requests without necessarily providing code changes?
explanation: **Issues** are for tracking ideas, feedback, tasks, or bugs. **Pull Requests** are for proposing actual code changes.
